children.name: like
children.definition: to think that something is nice, attractive, enjoyable etc:
examples: ▪ I like your dress - it’s a beautiful colour.
▪ Do you like spaghetti?

children.name: like something about something
examples: ▪ What did you like about the movie?

children.name: like doing something/like to do something
examples: ▪ I think Roy likes living alone.
▪ I like to see the children enjoying themselves.

children.name: be fond of sb/ stbe fond of  especially British
children.definition: to like something, especially something that you have liked for alongtime:
examples: ▪ Connie had always been fond of animals.
▪ He had always been fond of drinking at lunchtime, perhaps too fond.

children.name: be into
children.definition: to like doing a particular activity or be interested in a particular subject:
examples: ▪ I know she’s really into sports, so I thought I’d ask her to come skiing with us.
▪ A lot of his relatives are into very weird New Age stuff.

children.name: be keen on
children.definition: to like or be very interested in an activity or idea:
examples: ▪ I know he’s keen on opera. Let’s take him to see "La Traviata'.
▪ I’m quite keen on the idea of having a fancy dress party.

children.name: appeal to
children.definition: if something appeals to you, you like it because it involves things that interest you or ideas that you agree with:
examples: ▪ I’m sure this delightful book will appeal to children of all ages.
▪ Does either suggestion appeal to you?

children.name: go down wellalso go over well American
children.definition: if something you do, or a book, film, performance etc goes down well with a group of people, they like it:
examples: ▪ Her style of comedy is very British, but it goes down well in the States too.
go down well with
▪ At the present time, military action would not go over well with the international community

children.name: be to your liking
children.definition: if something is to your liking it has the qualities that you like, or it is made in the way that you like:
examples: ▪ Was the meal to your liking, Madam?
▪ The surrounding countryside was very much to our liking.

children.name: sb who likes st very much
lover
children.definition: someone who likes a particular activity very much:

children.name: music/car/wine/animal etc lover
examples: ▪ We are a nation of animal lovers.
▪ Every jazz lover dreams of visiting New Orleans.

children.name: lover of
examples: ▪ Lovers of night life won’t be able to resist the many nightclubs in the area.

children.name: fan
children.definition: someone who likes a particular sport, team, orfamousentertainer very much:
examples: ▪ Thousands of fans came to hear Oasis play.
▪ a football fan
fan of
▪ Fans of Sylvester Stallone will enjoy this movie.
fannoun[ C ]PERSON người hâm mộ;người say mê
someone who admires and supports a person, sport, sports team, etc
_More than 15, 000Liverpoolfans attended Saturday's game.
_He's a big fanofcountry music.
_I'm pleased to meet you – I'm a great fanofyour work.

children.name: enthusiast
children.definition: someone who likes a subject, activity, performer etc very much, is very interested in them and knows a lot about them:
examples: ▪ Enthusiasts are willing to pay up to $12,000 for an original copy of the book.

children.name: football/film/jazz etc enthusiast
examples: ▪ Golf enthusiasts will be able to see the tournament live on TV.
▪ The exhibition will be of interest to classic car owners and other motoring enthusiasts.

children.name: freak
children.definition: someone who is extremely interested in a particular activity, especially when other people think they are a little strange for liking it so much:

children.name: health/tv/sports etc freak
examples: ▪ Raw vegetables and nuts have always been a favourite with health-food freaks.
▪ One Beatle’s freak is reported to have paid $18,000 for Paul McCartney’s birth certificate.

children.name: junkie/addict
children.definition: someone who does, eats, watches etc something a lot because they enjoy it so much that they cannot stop doing it - use this especially when you do not think someone should be spending so much time doing or being involved in a particular thing:

children.name: TV/news/fast food etc junkie
examples: ▪ If you’re a shopping junkie, then this is the channel for you!
▪ You’d have to be a real political junkie to remember that Tsongas won the New Hampshire Primary in 1992.

children.name: TV/news/fast food etc addict
examples: ▪ My sons and my husband are all football addicts.

children.name: devotee
children.definition: someone who likes something such as art or literature very much and spends a lot of their time and money on it:
examples: ▪ He’s a devotee of old Hollywood movies.
▪ Urquhart, a rich devotee of the arts, made generous donations to the museum.

children.name: be crazy about stbe crazy aboutalsobe mad about somethingBritish
children.definition: informalto be extremely interested in an activity and spend a lot of time doing it or watching it:
examples: ▪ Jonah’s crazy about basketball.
▪ She’s always been mad about horses.

children.name: love/adore
children.definition: especially spoken to like something very much. Adore is stronger but less common than love:
examples: ▪ We had a great time at Disneyland. The kids loved it.
▪ I adore chocolate -- I could live on it.

children.name: love/adore doing something
examples: ▪ The older men loved hearing about Russ’s success on the football field.
▪ Jessie adored being the centre of attention.

children.name: be attached to
children.definition: to like something very much, especially something that you own or use, so that you would be upset if you lost it:
examples: ▪ Mom gets very attached to her pets.
▪ Casey had become quite attached to the comforts of his London home.

children.name: have a passion for
children.definition: to like an activity very much, because it gives you a lot of pleasure or excitement:
examples: ▪ From a very early age he had a passion for fast cars.
▪ To be a great performer, you have to work very hard and have a passion for the music you play.

children.name: be addicted to
children.definition: to enjoy doing something so much that you do it, watch it etc as often as you can and feel that you cannot stop doing it:
examples: ▪ My son’s addicted to computer games - he hardly ever comes out of his room.

children.name: be addicted
examples: ▪ I started watching the show out of curiosity, but now I’m addicted!

children.name: to like st that could be bad for you
can’t resist
children.definition: to like something so much that you cannot refuse it when it is offered to you:
examples: ▪ My mother could never resist expensive perfumes.

children.name: can’t resist doing something
examples: ▪ I couldn’t resist stopping by the bakery on the way home.

children.name: have a weakness for
children.definition: to like a particular kind of food, drink, or activity, even though you know it is not good for you or that other people might not approve of it:
examples: ▪ Too many of the men in our family have a weakness for alcohol.
▪ I have to admit I have a weakness for daytime soap operas.

children.name: be partial to
children.definition: to like something such as a particular food or drink, especially when you eat or drink it more than you should:
examples: ▪ He was particularly partial to my mother’s home-made wine.

children.name: not be averse to
children.definition: to like something or like doing something, especially something that could be bad or dangerous. This is often used humorously about something that is not really very bad:
examples: ▪ She’s not averse to the occasional glass of wine.

children.name: not be averse to doing something
examples: ▪ The company is highly competitive and not averse to taking risks.

children.name: get to like
children.definition: to begin to like something, especially something that you did not like at first:
examples: ▪ The more the two women talked, the more they got to like each other.
▪ I don’t think I could ever get to like hip-hop.

children.name: grow on
children.definition: if something grows on you, you gradually start to like it after a period of time:
examples: ▪ I didn’t like his accent much at first, but it kind of grows on you.

children.name: ▪ ‘The furniture in this place is a little weird.’ ‘Yeah, but it grows on you after a while.’
develop/acquire/get a taste for
children.definition: also develop a liking for something   to begin to like something that you did not like or had not experienced before:
examples: ▪ While Bev was married, she acquired a taste for luxurious living.
▪ When her family moved to Hollywood, she developed a liking for movie magazines and film culture.
▪ Sam soon got a taste for Thai green curry and sticky rice.

children.name: be an acquired taste
children.definition: if something is an acquired taste, people tend not to like when they first try it, but begin to like it when they have tried it a few more times:
examples: ▪ Dark beers and ales are an acquired taste, but there’s nothing better on a cold winter night.
▪ Like most modern jazz players, his music’s a bit of an acquired taste.

children.name: likes and dislikes
children.definition: all the things you like and do not like:
examples: ▪ She never lets her personal likes and dislikes affect the way she treats people.
▪ Employees were asked about their likes and dislikes, and also about how they felt about their working conditions.

children.name: sb’s passion/sb’s love /
children.definition: somebody’s passion/somebody’s love  something that you are deeply interested in and which you like so much that you are always excited about it:
examples: ▪ Donna’s latest passion is cooking and eating Mexican food.

children.name: somebody’s great/first love
examples: ▪ My father’s great love was fishing.

children.name: be fond of sb
children.definition: be fond of  to like someone very much, especially when you haveknownthem for alongtime:
examples: ▪ You’re very fond of Tyler, aren’t you?
▪ Over the years, the old man grew very fond of his nurse.

children.name: like
children.definition: to think someone has good qualities so that you feel friendly towards them:
examples: ▪ I’ve always liked Sally - she’s a lot of fun.
▪ Everybody liked Mr. Schofield, but he wasn’t a very good teacher.
▪ I never really liked her - she was always a bit stuck-up and condescending.

children.name: be attached to
children.definition: to like someone that you have known for a long time, so that you would be upset if they left you:
examples: ▪ We’ve grown quite attached to you, Annie, and we’ll be very sorry to see you leave.
▪ Nurses can easily get too attached to their patients.

children.name: have a soft spot for
children.definition: to like one person in particular more than the other people in a group:
examples: ▪ She’s always had a soft spot for her youngest grandson.
▪ I’ve had a soft spot for Janet ever since she took my side in the argument I had with Jimmy.

children.name: see st in
children.definition: see something in  to like someone because of a particular quality that they have, especially when other people do not notice that quality in them:
examples: ▪ Tom’s so innocent. He only sees the good in everyone he meets.
▪ I can’t figure out what Doug sees in her.

children.name: a man/woman after your own heart
children.definition: someone that you like because they have the same attitudes that you have, or like the same things that you like:
examples: ▪ I like the way she runs her business - a woman after my own heart.

children.name: hit it off
children.definition: if two people hit it off, they like each other, especially as soon as they meet:
examples: ▪ Art Howe asked him to come for an interview for the coaching job, and the two men hit it off immediately.
▪ Those two didn’t really hit it off at first, did they?

children.name: hit it off with
examples: ▪ You can’t expect to hit it off with everyone you meet.

children.name: get/grow/come to like
children.definition: to begin to like someone, especially someone that you did not like at first:
examples: ▪ At first I thought she was a bit weird, but now I’m getting to like her.
▪ Over the years, we grew to like each other, despite our differences.
▪ I’ve gradually come to like Larry and his eccentric habits.

children.name: warm to
children.definition: to begin to like someone and feel friendly towards them:
examples: ▪ Her heart warmed to Amos. He was obviously a man who loved animals.
▪ She was very nervous about introducing James to her children, but they warmed to him immediately.

children.name: take to/take a liking to
children.definition: to begin to like someone, especially when you have only known them for a very short time:
examples: ▪ I introduced Anders to my brother and they took to each other immediately.
▪ When Nicky takes to someone the way he’s taken to you, he’s your friend for life.
▪ They only met yesterday, but I can tell Jim’s taken a great liking to the girl.

children.name: endear yourself to
children.definition: to make someone like you by behaving in a way that pleases them:
examples: ▪ ‘Can I help you Mrs Killigarew’ he said, hoping to endear himself to her by remembering her name.
▪ She was witty and charming and quickly managed to endear herself to her future mother-in-law.

children.name: get on the right side of sbBritish informal also get on somebody’s good side American
children.definition: get on the right side of somebody informal   to do nice things for someone and avoid making them angry, in order to be sure they like you:
examples: ▪ He’s only sent me flowers because he’s trying to get on the right side of me.
▪ Chris doesn’t care what he has to say to get on Miller’s good side.

children.name: win the hearts of
children.definition: to make a lot of people like you very much, especially by doing something that they admire or approve of:
examples: ▪ With the words, ‘Ich bin ein Berliner,’ J.F. Kennedy won the hearts of millions of Germans.
▪ The slight, nervous-looking young gymnast won the hearts of a whole nation.
